about:
Hi!, I’m Daniel González, based in Berlin, Germany.

I’m a product designer with 18+ years of experience working for companies like Personio, HERE Technologies, Nokia, Frog Design, Telefónica I+D, elBullifoundation and others, across HR tech, fintech, automotive, IoT and data visualization products.

I’m a broad, experienced generalist who works across the full design spectrum, which gives me a holistic view of how products should look, feel and work. I combine visual design, UX, motion, and prototyping/development with an innovation mindset to discover better, more effective ways to solve problems and to make the brand tangible in every interaction.

I lead by doing: setting the bar through hands-on work, sharing tools and methods with the team, and creating a design culture where strong craft and systems thinking are the default.

In recent roles I’ve operated on two levels: on the craft side, redesigning core product experiences from the ground up and aligning product and brand into a more modern, coherent interface; and on the system side, defining standards, workflows and internal tools that make that level of quality scalable. I’ve built design-ops tooling to automate on-brand asset creation and reduce review overhead, so designers and developers can focus on the highest-impact parts of the product. This approach addresses a common growth problem: how to keep raising the quality bar while the organization scales.

Additionally, I mentor around accessibility and inclusive design, because every person should have equal access to information in their everyday life.

projects.name: Personio Rebrand
projects.subtitle: Rebranding the company's visual identity
projects.description:
Personio is one of the big HR players in Europe, and when the company prepared to enter the North American market—a market with louder, more established competitors—it became clear the product and the brand had to tell the same, stronger story. Not just a new landing page, but a unified experience across product, marketing, and motion.

Overhauling the Product

We started from the inside out, with the product. Personio’s app was growing fast and teams were shipping in parallel, so the first step was a robust UX architecture: shared navigation patterns, layout rules, page templates, and a way to plug in new modules without breaking coherence. We didn’t try to fix everything at once—we went squad by squad, product area by product area, reviewing and overhauling.

Inside the product, we introduced full customization for customers: many of Personio’s clients want their HR tools to reflect their own brand. That meant our color system had to be themable. We designed tokens and elevation rules that could accept a client’s primary color and still produce accessible UI states, charts, inputs, and alerts—every component had to scale regardless of the base color a customer chose.

We also designed micro-interactions—loaders, spinners, home-screen loading behavior, panel transitions—to make the product feel alive and premium without being distracting. Motion became part of the brand expression inside the product.

Rebranding

After about a year of stabilizing and upgrading the product experience, we shifted focus to the brand itself. Redesigning the brand in six months was ambitious, but we built a multidisciplinary squad where each person owned a vertical—color, tone of voice, illustration, iconography, motion, web—and we iterated together so nothing felt disconnected. The result was a brand that feels more premium and confident, yet warm and people-centric.

The first item on the list was to refresh the logotype to align with where the company was going—still recognizably Personio, but cleaner, more confident, and easier to apply across digital surfaces.

Redefining How the Product Is Shown & Sold

We reimagined how the product is told and sold—sharpening the tone of voice, shifting to product-first storytelling, and using interactive motion to make the UI feel alive. Scroll-based reveals and purposeful micro-interactions turn features into experiences, elevating perceived quality. Sales materials were rebuilt to match—clearer value props and demo flows that mirror the site—so the entire journey feels modern, premium, and consistently on-brand.

Distribution & Scale

We documented the essentials in Figma and shipped a component library so teams could move fast without divergence. We art-directed the few places that needed extra polish. Instead of a 120-page brand PDF, we built internal tools—image and illustration generators with vector/PNG export, plus motion helpers for intros/outros. Result: the brand became deployable at speed, and always on-brand.

projects.name: HUG
projects.subtitle: Designing the launching experience.
projects.description:
HUG — Personio’s annual launch event — is where the company shows what’s coming next: new products, upcoming features, and a clearer story about the future of HR. For this edition I led the design of the keynote experience, and the goal was to do more than “show screens.” We wanted an experience that framed the announcements inside a story people could remember.

The core concept was the lighthouse — a symbol for guidance and clarity, always visible even in rough conditions. That matched what Personio was launching: products that help HR teams see further into their operations, act faster, and stay oriented even when the business context is changing. The message was: Personio is the light in a complex HR landscape.

Visually, the lighthouse idea cascaded into the whole environment: stage lighting that behaved like moving beams, gradients and shadows suggesting depth. It also made the whole thing more cinematic — we could use motion, pacing, and narration to guide attention. We even crafted a music layer for the event — cues for entries, reveals, and transitions — so the rhythm of the keynote matched the narrative beats. Presentation materials felt premium — clean typography, confident color, and enough negative space to make every message land. We designed event materials (signage, screen frames, badges) to live in the same ecosystem so the experience felt coherent across keynote, venue, and comms.

We were careful with legibility on stage: high contrast, simple layouts, motion used to support the story (not compete with it), music timed to moments of emphasis, and speaker positioning planned so they never blocked key content on screen. The result was a product launch that felt guided, premium, and unmistakably Personio, even without showing the full product UI on stage.

projects.name: Klar
projects.subtitle: Transforming Mexican's financial experience
projects.description:
Klar had just gotten its banking license, which basically meant: we weren’t just a nice fintech anymore — we could operate as a real bank, people’s money was protected, and we had to look and behave like something you can actually trust with your savings. That opened the door to overhaul two things at once: the product experience and the brand.

The goal was clear: make Klar feel more premium without losing the very Mexican, very warm tone people already liked. Not premium as in cold and corporate — premium as in thoughtful, clear, and built for people here. The tone of voice had to stay casual and ‘de confianza,’ because in Mexico money products work better when they feel close, almost family-like.

We defined the brand values — access, freedom, clarity, transparency — and used them as the backbone for everything. Access and clarity became interfaces that show the most relevant information first, with no clutter. Transparency meant no hidden states and no ‘where is my money?’ moments. And freedom — in the sense of financial freedom — was the core feeling we wanted the whole experience to evoke.

Visually we kept it mature but still vibrant, echoing Mexican culture: warm neutrals, greens, lots of white background, black text for legibility. Iconography and photography were localized — people, objects and scenes that actually look like Mexico, not generic fintech stock.

It wasn’t just a repaint. We revisited the information architecture: what lives on the home screen, how you move between card, payments, savings, credit, and how quickly you can understand your money status at a glance.

Once the new visual language and patterns were solid, we turned it into a proper design system so the team could redesign the rest of the app without reinventing components. Tokens, spacing, type scales, cards, list rows, alerts — all documented. Then we worked with engineering to migrate components so they rendered 1:1 with the system — design and code connected at the core. That cut down screen-by-screen QA, reduced duplicated code, and gave both designers and developers a single source of truth.

Impact. After the redesign, Klar was able to grow into one of the most popular digital banking experiences in the region without having to refresh the look & feel every year. The system stayed relevant because it wasn’t just ‘pretty UI’ — it was design plus design ops as a scaling tool: a clear brand, a tidy architecture, and a robust system that let the team ship faster, more consistently, and with the same voice.

projects.name: WeGo Deliver
projects.subtitle: Empowering small businesses to thrive through delivery services.
projects.description:
When the pandemic hit and cities went into lockdown, a lot of small businesses and restaurants suddenly lost their walk-in customers, while delivery requests shot up. People still wanted cakes, food, groceries — but most of these businesses didn’t have the digital setup to switch that fast, and they still wanted to keep their teams working. This wasn’t just one city; we were seeing the same pattern everywhere.

Right in the middle of that, my friend Guadalupe — she runs a pastry shop — called me and said: ‘Hey, does HERE have something that helps me go fully delivery?’ Inside HERE we were already working on a LastMile product… but it wasn’t public yet. Telling her to ‘wait for the launch’ didn’t make sense. So we looked for a shortcut, found an open-source API from the same team, and decided to build a leaner tool on top of it. I pulled a small team together and the brief was very clear: make it real, fast.

We did have a lot of LastMile research at HERE, but most of it was for big operators — fleets, dispatchers, integrated systems. That doesn’t map 1:1 to a bakery. So we talked directly to the people we wanted to help: how many stops they do per day, what vehicles they use, how they transport products, how comfortable they are with tech. The pattern was obvious: planning routes by hand takes time, it’s easy to make mistakes, and keeping customers updated on arrivals is annoying. That’s basically the travelling-salesman problem — and that part we already knew how to solve.

From there we went UX-first. The biggest friction wasn’t routing, it was importing. Most people can export something from Excel, but they won’t clean a CSV. So we designed the ‘add orders’ step to do the work: accept different CSVs, infer columns, auto-map addresses, and only stop to ask for more when it couldn’t guess. The idea was: if you have a file, the app should adapt to you — not the other way around. We kept it mobile-first too, because a lot of owners run their business from their phone.

We also didn’t want it to look like a side project. While we were building, I synced with brand, content, and the WeGo team so naming, tone, and visuals matched the rest of HERE. That made the rollout smoother. After a few iterations — about three months — we were ready to go public, and I worked with brand/marketing on launch assets (video, blog, social) so the tool actually reached the small businesses we built it for.

The response was the best part. People wrote to say thanks for making it free during all the changing rules. NGOs used it to deliver food to schools in low-income areas during holidays. Internally, it turned into a little innovation space inside the LastMile team — a place to try ideas, validate with real users, and push the UX/UI bar — and it ended up in our social responsibility comms as a good example of design + speed actually helping people.

projects.name: Designing Data & Insights
projects.subtitle: Turning Personio into an intelligent insights platform
projects.description:
As Personio moved toward a data-driven product strategy, we focused on company-wide impact: giving every team a shared language for data, a repeatable way to ship insights, and the skills to use them. The objective wasn’t just better charts, it was faster delivery, fewer inconsistencies, clearer decisions, and a product story that sales, marketing, and product could all stand behind.

System Design

We created the building blocks for a company standard: responsive chart and insight components, dashboard and detail patterns, tokens instead of hard-coded colors, and clear rules for hierarchy, spacing, and typography. For teams, this meant fewer one-off decisions, less rework, and faster reviews. For the company, it meant brand-consistent insights across products without sacrificing accessibility or theming for enterprise customers.

Interactions

We standardized interaction—interactive legends, isolate/show behaviors, time navigation, zoom/pan, and transition rules—so teams stopped inventing bespoke patterns. Result: fewer edge-case bugs, faster QA, and a familiar exploration model that reduced cognitive load for customers.

Accessibility

Accessibility was built in from day one: color-blind-safe palettes, robust contrast, and screen-reader structures. The token system mapped safely to customer brand colors, so sales could promise white-label flexibility without risking readability or meaning—reducing custom exceptions and implementation time.

Redesigning the ‘Analytics’ Experience

We applied the system to Analytics, one of Personio’s heaviest data products. Clearer entry points, fewer steps, and ready-made views for common HR questions shortened time-to-insight for non-analysts. For teams, shared components plus clearer flows meant faster shipping and easier cross-team collaboration; for the business, a more compelling upsell story around reporting.

Insights with AI

We explored an AI layer to surface what changed, flag outliers, and summarize “what matters this month” in plain language. Designed as pragmatic flows tied to the roadmap, this gave product and sales a credible path to unlock value on large datasets—without specialist training.

Impact

The system set the visual, interaction, and accessibility standard for data at Personio. Teams shipped faster with fewer divergences; onboarding and reviews got lighter thanks to shared guidelines; sales and marketing told one consistent story; and customers experienced insights that felt coherent across reporting, attendance, and payroll. In short: higher quality, lower friction, and a company that could scale insights with confidence.

projects.name: Piel
projects.description:
Piel. A visual investigation into time, memory, and identity through the language of the skin. The face, as a sensitive surface, becomes a living archive where personal and collective history leave their traces: folds, wrinkles, scars, transformations. Each portrait is a mirror of time and, at once, an invitation to contemplate the beauty of different skin tones and the singular way each one ages.

It’s a digital art project that treats human skin as a living map — a surface where time leaves its marks, where memories, love, and loss are etched in subtle lines and textures. Through interactive visuals and poetic elements, the work invites viewers to reflect on their own skin as an archive of experiences.

It’s an experiment at the intersection of art, technology, and human storytelling.

projects.name: HERE Style Editor
projects.subtitle: Designing a cartographic experience
projects.description:
HERE Style Editor was built for a new wave of designers working on in-car and automotive experiences — people who care about brand and usability but shouldn’t have to become cartographers to change a map. Map design is usually very technical (layers, zoom levels, road classes, accessibility, cultural symbols), and most tools at the time were made for mapping experts. We started from a solid HERE base map and added a friendlier layer on top.

Designers could use global color filters, brand palettes, and numeric multipliers to resize whole families of features — like all roads — at once. Power users still had access to the deep cartography panel, but everyone else could quickly make a readable, on-brand map for the car screen without breaking legibility or accessibility.

projects.name: HERE Marketplace
projects.subtitle: Designing a shopping experience for location data
projects.description:
For several years, HERE Technologies’ goal has been to become the leading location platform — a place where HERE and third-party data products work seamlessly, plug easily into visualization tools and services, and can be sourced, bought, and sold through the HERE Marketplace.

Map data at HERE came from many different sources, in different formats, often measured in terabytes, and usually had to be parsed through different APIs. That made it hard for customers to evaluate the quality of the data and decide what to buy. Very often sales had to jump in — sometimes even pulling in a whole team of engineers — just to help a client see a sample. The process worked, but it wasn’t efficient.

The goal of the marketplace was to change that: let customers discover, preview, and buy data from HERE and third parties without having to talk to sales every single time. We already had the technology and the exploratory API tools — the real challenge was to put them behind a single, purposeful experience. Most of the design work was actually about hiding a fragmented, messy tech stack behind a clean, predictable interface.

We made ‘preview before purchase’ the core of the journey. Instead of building a brand-new map engine, we reused internal capabilities and exposed them in a simpler UI. That allowed users to pick an area of interest, see coverage or a sample for that exact location, and then proceed to buy or subscribe. For products that couldn’t yet expose real-time previews — like Lidar or more complex bundles — we designed rich fallback blocks (visuals, coverage illustrations, better product storytelling) so they could still live in the same marketplace without breaking the layout.

In the end, the marketplace became self-serve. Customers could understand what they were buying, narrow it to the region they cared about, and start faster. And it had a direct business impact: support and sales no longer had to spend time sending manual samples or explaining coverage over and over, so they could focus on higher-value prospects. Less repetitive work for the company, faster decisions for customers.

projects.name: LUI Data
projects.subtitle: Data Visualization
projects.description:
A design system focused on data visualization. Our scalable components have been crafted with the needs of designers building data-driven products in mind. With a comprehensive collection of commonly used charts, our system makes it easy to create visually compelling dashboards.

A plugin to creating maps using dummy data is an especially powerful feature of LUI Data. It streamlines the process of mockup maps for navigation and data visualization purposes, allowing designers to focus on the big picture rather than the minutiae of map creation.

Our color palettes have also been designed to be highly accessible, mapped for various scales such as sequential, diverging, and categorical, so that all users can benefit from our system.

In addition to these features, we've also created a set of comprehensive guides that aid designers in selecting the best chart or map to tell their data story. Whether you're new to data visualization or an experienced data professional, our guides offer invaluable insights to help you make the best decisions.

Developing our LUI Data required extensive research and analysis. We studied all the products across the organization to define a reduced set of components that are flexible enough to support all products but limited enough to minimizing design errors. The result is a powerful and versatile design system that empowers designers to create exceptional data products with ease and precision.

projects.name: Arise & Shine App
projects.description:
Arise and Shine is what happens when an alarm clock and your morning routine decide to work together instead of ruining your life separately.

It’s a wake-up app built for “I really need 10 more minutes” days. You can snooze like a normal human, but the app is actually smart about it: every time you hit snooze, it quietly adjusts your morning routine in the background — skipping something small or shortening a task — and eventually tells you, “okay, that’s it, if you snooze again you’ll be late.”

So instead of a passive alarm that just yells at you, Arise and Shine manages two things at once: your sleepiness, your schedule. You get extra sleep when you need it, and you still make it out the door on time — just maybe without the 15-step skincare routine that day. Designed for real mornings, not ideal ones.
